text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE,

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graham)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Mrs. E.H. Olmstead (nee Milly Parley)
Present Address: Gregg, Man.
Pioneer Address: Moffat R.R. via Walsley, Sask.
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1885

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1934, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? About 6 homes - from 1 to 10 miles away.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? Some bachelors visited us.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Once or twice in winter, to each home of our special friends.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Always on weekdays.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Asked to come anytime.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Usually afternoon.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Always asked, no excuse made, the food shared with the family. The meal was not cooked after visitors arrived.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? A cup of tea, with home baking; usually Scotch seconds made on top of stove, served with butter.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Usually all went, in winter time.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? No.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. Not many in our district in the early years, when children grew up they were popular. Most of the early settlers were young married couples, who were raising a family & working hard at mixed farming.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. Yes, about 1902. Sleigh loads would gather at a farm house, bringing lunch along. Sometimes unexpected crowds arrived, all made welcome.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No, but crowds had usual homes where they went to quilt often.
SASKATCHEWAN APPEARANCES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Flower Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

4. What time of the day did you go—in the morning and spend the day or in the afternoon, etc.? Usually after dinner.

That about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "make pot luck" used, or was some other expression common?)

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "meets" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, whilst driving our dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? (About 1925)

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? (Country)

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)(for all gatherings)

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? Usually the young folk attended.

How were babies and small children provided for? (single married)

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? People had more for a few teams in this farm.

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Whist

Was there card playing for a prize? No.

What dances were popular? Very few dances in a Presbyterian Scotch Settlement.

Some homes had dances, Scotch reel, but mostly square dances, Waltz-Weaver dances Latin.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Some families would not play cards at all. "Devil's book!" This too became part of the social life later on.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, planters, etc.)

If you have not described these in the school questionnaire, give data.

9. What was your first community hall built? (A.D. 1925)

How large was it?

What material was it made of?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? )

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 9, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Some families had dances in their own homes.

Has there ever any ill-temperment between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Some families would not play cards at all. Would you?

The Tox Town part of the social life was...
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? 
Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Just friendly gatherings, friendly games, singing, etc. Such games as charades, Kingdom, musical chairs, etc.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Y.P.Society, which we called a Mutual Improvement Association.
Give the date and reason for it being organized. 1885. They met in the church, these meetings helped the young people become good citizens. Meetings were continued for several winters, used to the improvement of the community.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? No.
Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? Yes.
When was it organized?
Approximately how many women belonged to it?
Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What attempts at formality or "snobbishness" do you remember in small towns, such as cities and towns when visiting, calling cards, calling on people, etc.?

13. Was the athletics known in your community? Describe what you remember about athletics, telling how women they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Remember any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when these changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS:

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community? Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Baptist church in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.?

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Ball games were very common.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? Both skipping rope & play house were popular. Children were much the same down the years.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the names of each, date when it was first organized, its activities, its aims and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included colored people only or was relatively small (for example, within a school district) or was located in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There are spaces in the chart given which indicate the organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here.)

What names were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures? Talk on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (swimming, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (satisfying rope, play house, etc.)?

With what children were you most familiar?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 
   *Skating* after school would be taught. Playing out in the snow kept children active & amused.

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games? 
   *Checker* was made a popular game. Few games could be bought until 1900. Parents taught the children some of their childhood games, such as "blind man's buff". They wrote a common list. Pothooks were very popular with a crowd of young folk. Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain. 
   *Children* grew up enjoying the fun together & times.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain. 
   *Time was found for games - all children had a happy time together. Work for the adults, & children were taught to help with the work too.*

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gopher or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe. 
   *All children invent games to suit their fancy. No special game lasted for long.*

**Picnics and Sports**

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? 
   *Give year and month if possible.* 
   *3rd July 1888.*

26. Who organized it? 

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 
   *For the community.*

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? 
   *As far as I know.*

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? 
   *Ball games & races. Dancing for its children.*

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? 
   *Families brought the sandwiches & cakes, & all food was passed around. We all sat on the grass under the trees.*

31. What did you have to eat and drink? 
   *Sandwiches, cake, cooking, etc. were served with tea. (Milk for children)*

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? 
   *Some came about 11 a.m., others during the afternoon. All went home after supper. Evening chores had to be done.*
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.
It was a trip day for the children.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc. Around 1896 this picnic was held on the church grounds, & from then on became "the 1st July Sunday School picnic at Moffat." Tables were built under the trees & all brought food for the meals. Food much the same during the years sandwiches, cake, pie. All free. A booth where homemade ice cream & candy was sold.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable. About 1906 - salad became popular & cold meat, fruit supplies, with scalloped potatoes, pickles, jellies, etc. No free meals.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people). Not many old people in the early days, so nearly everyone took part in sports.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams? Football

What year? 1908 How long did it continue? Several years.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc. Baseball. Local & neighboring district.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.). We skated on the sloughs. The boys played hockey to amuse themselves. Several families kept their own slough ready & had parties. When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for? None in our district. We used to go to the Wolseley rink once or twice a winter, after we learned to skate in 1908.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drinks, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

That year: 1908

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1910, playing date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities, played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local parks, etc., in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

Show how the first indoor rink was built, and what was used for (hockey, skating, etc.).
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1896.
Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? Really the same.
Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? We called it our local sports day of "trifling sports".
When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st). July 1st.

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary.)
Mother brought several books from Scotland.
The Bible was our main interest. Pilgrim's Progress & Bible stories. Annie Swan's books, etc., etc.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? Those who liked reading had none.
What kind of books and how many? Story books, but they were heavy to pack, so few in number.

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?
Those who liked reading did exchange.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.
Not many in the early years.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? Bible stories, were sent to us children, from Scotland. Picture books.

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.
Most before 1914.

48. Was there a school library? Small one. When was it begun? 1899.
To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?
All books were well read by those who liked reading.

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
Only to help the children.
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1894.

Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? Yes

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? Mr. Smith

What was the sports day usually held? (What month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 4th)

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors, if possible. If not, tell as nearly as possible how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? (Give details.)

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?

48. Was there a school library? Small one. When was it begun? 1899

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started? Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   Old Country Papers were sent to my parents. Later on we got Way Free Press, Montreal Witness, Farm Journal from U.S.A., & our local Wolseley News.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? No.
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
   Tried to make the best of what we could get to read. We didn't know very much about the rest of the world during the early days in the west.
8.

50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started?
   Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian,
and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to
    this west? (Tell when and what they were.)

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped cer-
    tain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading
    material?
    Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your
    early days in the west a hardship? Explain. (Tell how the lack of reading
    material affected you and how you met the need.)
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? None.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Violin, sometimes a mouth organ.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

An Organ - May 1904 - price $36.00

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

Singing very popular. First organ was brought in by an ex-music teacher in 1885. She taught us to all concerts & helped with music part of the program.

In the community? Were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.? Describe.

Yes, the settlers were fond of music.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? Sketch songs.

In the community? Mostly Sketch songs.

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

Yes, for concerts.

63. Was there a band in your community? When was it started?

Who started it? How long did it continue?

How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?

What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
Musical Experiences

56. What musical instruments did you bring with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the school? Give dates, places, if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home life? In early years in the Navy barracks, during World War I, etc.? In the community? Were there musical groups, parties, etc., where music was played?

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the house?

In the Community

61. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody? If so, explain.

63. Has there been a band in your community? If so, who started it? How long did it continue? Who was bandmaster?

Tell what you remember of the activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the nation? If so, give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is there an important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections," such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of the collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
Oxford

No. 613 S
